2.title: Part 1 - Quick start of creating personal site
2.content: Create Github repository. | Login github.com and create a repository with the following settings. | . Repository Name: {Owner} / {username}.github.ioPublic or private: PublicAdd a README file: CheckedAdd .gitignore template: Jekyll . Enable Github Pages by settings. | Open the created repository. | Click tab â€œSettingsâ€ > menu item â€œPagesâ€. | . Source: Deply from a branchBranch: Main / (root) . Apply Jekyll theme. (optional) . The step is optional. If you want to see how it is easy to quickly enable Jekyll theme, following the steps below. | Create a â€œ_config.ymlâ€ file in the root folder of the repository. | Copy the code into the file and save it. | . # _config.yml file.remote_theme: pages-themes/hacker@v0.2.0plugins:- jekyll-remote-themetitle: my site titledescription: my site description. | Click tab â€œActionsâ€ > â€œAll workflowsâ€. One or two workflow is created automatically because of code repository changes detected by Github Actions. | If the latest workflow runs as below, the deployment of your site is completed successfully. | . Visit personal site. Open https://{username}.github.io.

3.title: Part 2 - Set up local development and CI/CD environment. (Windows)
3.content: In the real world, we normally need a local development environment which allows us to code, local debugging and testing. It doesnâ€™t need deploy uncompleted work to remote website every time. In this section, we will lead you step by step for how to set the local development using Microsoft Visual Studio within Windows system. Install Ruby on Windows . | Download latest Ruby+DevKit package (my version is Ruby+Devkit 3.4.4-2 (x64)) from the site https://rubyinstaller.org/downloads/. | Run installer and select all components. | At the last stage of installation, following the instructions to continue the installation in the pop-up command window. | Open a new command window, enter â€œruby -vâ€ and â€œgem -vâ€ to verify. | Installed ruby and gem versions will look like below if all is installed successfully. | . Install Jekyll . | Open a new command window. Run â€œgem install jekyll bundlerâ€. | Verify after installation completed by command â€œjekyll -vâ€. | . Configure Jekyll Theme . | Go to local project root folder, for example â€œxxx.github.ioâ€. | Assume the â€œ_config.ymlâ€ file is configured as below (following part 1 step 3). | . # _config.yml file.remote_theme: pages-themes/hacker@v0.2.0plugins:- jekyll-remote-themetitle: my site titledescription: my site description. | Open a new command window. Navigate to root folder. | Run â€œbundle initâ€ command. â€œGemfileâ€ will be generated if it isnâ€™t there. | Open â€œGemfileâ€. Add the following 3 lines and save it. | . # Gemfilegem "jekyll"gem "jekyll-seo-tag"gem "jekyll-remote-theme" . | In the same command window, run â€œbundle installâ€. | Listed packages in Gemfile will be installed. | . Â Important tips: . | If there is any error for missing packages, put â€œgem {pakcage name}â€ in Gemfile and run â€œbundle installâ€ again. | For some region (like China), the default Ruby source site â€œhttps://rubygems.orgâ€ might not be accessible or instable. You need config an accessible mirror source site before run â€œbundle installâ€. For exmple: in the same command window, run the command. | . # Change mirror Ruby source site.C:\Users>bundle config mirror.https://rubygems.org https://gems.ruby-china.com . Build and run local site . | Keep at the root folder in command window. | Run â€œjekyll buildâ€ to complie the site. | Run â€œjekyll serverâ€ to run the site. | Open browser to visit the local site (default: â€œhttp://localhost:4000â€). | . Â Q&A of common problems and errors . | Â Error: Liquid Exception: invalid byte sequence in UTF-8â€¦ Â If UTF-8 is asked, source files must use UTF-8 encoding. To make it corrected, In â€œNotepadâ€, â€œSave Asâ€ and select encoding as â€œUTF-8â€. In â€œVisual Studioâ€, change default environment setting by â€œToolsâ€ > â€œOptionsâ€ > â€œEnvironmentâ€ > â€œDocumentsâ€. | Â Error: When run â€œjekyll buildâ€, sometimes it says version incompatiblility error. Â Run â€œbundle clean â€“forceâ€. Then reinstall by â€œbundle installâ€ command. | Â Tip: Change configured mirror Ruby source site. Â Run command line. # Change mirror Ruby source site.C:\Users>bundle config mirror.https://rubygems.org https://gems.ruby-china.com . | Â Error: You have already activated jekyll-sass-converter 3.1.0, but your Gemfile requires jekyll-sass-converter 3.0.0. Prepending bundle exec to your command may solve this. (Gem::LoadError). Â After all methods tried, there is still error. Prepending â€œbundle execâ€ to the command. For example, use â€œbundle exec jekyll serveâ€ to start the jekyll web service. # Add "bundle exec" befor command.C:\Users>bundle exec jekyll serve . | Â Error: certificate verify failed (unable to get certificate CRL) (OpenSSL::SSL::SSLError) (Gem::LoadError). (Oct-25, error in my MacOS) Â Install openssl by command â€œgem install opensslâ€, then update project â€œGemfileâ€ with â€œgem â€œopensslâ€â€. # Install openssl.C:\Users>gem install openssl . # Add openssl into project Gemfile...gem "openssl"... | Â Error: ERROR: SSL verification error at depth 1: unable to get local issuer certificate (20) ERROR: You must add /C=US/O=Internet Security Research Group/CN=ISRG Root X1 to your local trusted store Â  . | Download the cacert.pem file from SRG Root X1 certificate. | Save it to a local foder. For example: C:\Ruby34-x64\ssl\cacert.pem | Manually set up the system environment variable set SSL_CERT_FILE to the file location. | . set SSL_CERT_FILE=C:\Ruby34-x64\ssl\cacert.pem . | Run â€œgem update â€“systemâ€ | Run â€œridk installâ€ | . | . References: . | https://docs.github.com/en/pages | https://jekyllrb.com/docs | https://pages.github.com/themes | .

5.title: Table of contents
5.content: . | Page structure | Posts list page - â€œblog/index.htmlâ€ | Create post layout page â€œ_layouts/post.htmlâ€ | Create .md files in folder â€œ_postsâ€ | Final result | . Prerequisite: This post assumes you have already a website built using Jekyll template.

6.title: Page structure
6.content: highlighted are used specifically for posts.) . Root Folder . assets . css images js . blog . index.html . _data _includes _layouts _posts _sass . index.html about.md .

7.title: Posts list page - â€œblog/index.htmlâ€
7.content: --- layout: default title: BLOG --- <h1>Latest Posts</h1> <ul class="blog__container"> {% for post in site.posts %} <li> <h3><a href="{{ post.url }}">{{ post.title }}</a><span>&nbsp;|&nbsp;{{ post.date | date_to_string }}</span></h3> <span>{{ post.excerpt }}</span> </li> {% endfor %} </ul> .

8.title: Create post layout page â€œ_layouts/post.htmlâ€
8.content: The layout file will be use for all posts. --- layout: default --- <h1>{{ page.title }}</h1> <p class="post__author__date">{{ page.author }}, {{ page.date | date_to_string }}</p> {{ content }} .

9.title: Create .md files in folder â€œ_postsâ€
9.content: File name follows the pattern â€œ2025-01-1-filename.mdâ€. --- layout: post author: my name title: this is my first post. excerpt: My first post summary. --- # Welcome to my blog. ***Helo world=***, this is my first blog post.

10.title: Final result
10.content: . | Build and run Jekyll: â€œjekyll serveâ€; | Go to â€œhttp://localhost:4000/blogâ€; | Posts are listed in the page; | Click the link to one post to open the post page. | .

12.title: Table of contents
12.content: . | Install â€œjekyll-paginateâ€ plugin. | Enable pagination in _config.yml. | Update blog HTML page to render the pagination. | .

13.title: Install â€œjekyll-paginateâ€ plugin.
13.content: . | Update â€œGemfileâ€ to include the plugin. # Gemfile filegem "jekyll-paginate" . | Open a new command window. | Navigate to project root folder. | Run â€œbundle installâ€ command. | .

14.title: Enable pagination in _config.yml.
14.content: . | Add additional configuration in â€œ_config.ymlâ€ file. # _config.yml filepaginate: 5paginate_path: "/blog/page:num/" . | .

15.title: Update blog HTML page to render the pagination.
15.content: For example, if you have â€œblog.htmlâ€ to list all posts. {% if paginator.total_pages > 1 %} <div class="pagination"> {% if paginator.previous_page %} <a href="{{ paginator.previous_page_path | relative_url }}">« Prev</a> {% else %} <span>« Prev</span> {% endif %}<br/> {% for page in (1..paginator.total_pages) %} {% if page == paginator.page %} <em>{{ page }}</em> {% elsif page == 1 %} <a href="{{ site.paginate_path | relative_url | replace: 'page:num/', '' }}">{{ page }}</a> {% else %} <a href="{{ site.paginate_path | relative_url | replace: ':num', page }}">{{ page }}</a> {% endif %} {% endfor %} {% if paginator.next_page %} <a href="{{ paginator.next_page_path | relative_url }}">Next »</a> {% else %} <span>Next »</span> {% endif %} </div> {% endif %} . | Open a new command window. | Navigate to project root folder. | Run â€œjekyll serveâ€ command to start the website. | .

16.title: Enable pagination
16.content: Reference: Pagination | Jekyll . Notes: Pagination only works with HTML files.

17.title: Table of contents
17.content: . | Create a new page for grouping by Tag or Cetegory. | /blog/categories.html | . Notes: If page belongs to more tags or categories, use â€œtags: a, b, câ€ or â€œcategories: a, b, câ€.

18.title: Create a new page for grouping by Tag or Cetegory.
18.content: Taking Category as example, create a page called â€œ/blog/categories.htmlâ€. Put the following code and test if it works. --- layout: default title: Categories --- <div class="blog__container"> {% for category in site.categories %} {% capture category_name %}{{ category | first }}{% endcapture %} <h3 class="category-head">{{ category_name }}</h3> <a name="{{ category_name | slugize }}"></a> {% for post in site.categories[category_name] %} <h4 style="margin: 2px;"><a href="{{ post.url }}">{{ post.title }}</a><span>&nbsp;|&nbsp;{{ post.date | date_to_string }}</span></h4> {% endfor %} <p></p> {% endfor %} </div> .

49.title: Steps
49.content: . | Find the latest mermaid javascript (cdnjs as example): https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mermaid/11.5.0/mermaid.min.js | Include the following scripts in html page or layout page. | . <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en-US"> <head> ... <script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mermaid/11.5.0/mermaid.min.js" type="text/javascript"></script> ... </head> <body> ... <script> var config = { startOnLoad: true, theme: 'forest', flowchart: { useMaxWidth: false, htmlLabels: true } }; mermaid.initialize(config); window.mermaid.init(undefined, document.querySelectorAll('.language-mermaid')); </script> </body> </html> .

50.title: Test by adding mermaid code block
50.content: ```mermaid %%{init: {"flowchart": {"htmlLabels": false}} }%% flowchart LR markdown["`This **is** _Markdown_`"] newLines["`Line1 Line 2 Line 3`"] markdown --> newLines ``` . %%{init: {"flowchart": {"htmlLabels": false}} }%% flowchart LR markdown["`This **is** _Markdown_`"] newLines["`Line1 Line 2 Line 3`"] markdown --> newLines .

51.title: Optional: tips of changing chart style
51.content: By default, the chart is rendered based on the site css styles. Sometimes, the style doesnâ€™t satisfy requirements. One problem I encountered is, my site background is black and the lines between shapes are also with black color. This made the lines invisible. To fix this problem, I use css selector to find the rendered objects <pre>. The mermaid markdown code is rendered as the following. <pre><code class="language-mermaid" data-processed="true"> <svg ...>...</svg></code></pre> . Select <pre> using (has) combinator and class â€œlanguage-mermaidâ€ which is rendered by mermaid. Then change css style. Hereâ€™s the css Iâ€™m using. <style> /* mermaid */ pre:has(code.language-mermaid) { background-color:wheat !important; } </style> .

57.title: Install svg-pan-zoom plugin
57.content: . | Goto https://github.com/bumbu/svg-pan-zoom | Download â€œsvg-pan-zoom.min.jsâ€ file. | Include the javascript file in web page. | Call init method. | . Sample code block (mermaid chart as example). Tip: Mermaid.js often generates SVGs dynamically, so need to wait for them to appear. (DOMContentLoaded) Tip: To change the default svg width as â€œ100%â€. <head> ... <script src="/assets/js/svg-pan-zoom.min.js" type="text/javascript"></script> ... </head> <body> ... <script> //.... /** svg-pan-zoom plugin */ document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () { var svgElements = document.querySelectorAll('.language-mermaid > svg') console.log("DOMContentLoaded " + svgElements.length); if (svgElements.length > 0) { svgElements.forEach(el => { var panZoomInstance = svgPanZoom(`#${el.id}`, { zoomEnabled: true, controlIconsEnabled: true, fit: true, center: true }); var panZoomContainer = el.querySelector('.svg-pan-zoom-control'); if (panZoomContainer) { // debugger; panZoomContainer.style.transform = "translate(0, 0) scale(0.7)"; } }); } }); </script> </body> .

Make sure this is descriptive enough that most people will understand what youâ€™re working on. | Project managerWho is the point of contact for this project? | Last revision dateYour project charter is a living document. Including the last revision date can be helpful for team members who are frequently checking back on the charter. | Project purposeWhy are you working on this project? | Project objectivesWhat deliverables and assets do you plan to achieve by the end of the project? | Project scopeWhat are the boundaries of your project deliverables? 65.title: Example1 - load .csv data
65.content: <div id="container__1"></div> <script> d3.csv('/assets/data/food.csv', function(data){ return { "food": data.Food, "deliciousness": data.Deliciousness } }).then(function(dataset){ // console.log("dataset", dataset); var body = d3.select("#container__1"); body.selectAll ("p") .data(dataset) .enter() .append("p") .text(function(d){ return d.food; }).style("color", function(d){ return "rgb(0, " + d.deliciousness * 255 + ", 255)"; }) }); </script> .

66.title: Example2 - Draw Circles
66.content: <div id="container__2"></div> <script> var dataset2 = [5, 10, 15, 20, 25]; var w = 500; var h= 100; var svg = d3.select("#container__2") .append("svg") .attr("width", w) .attr("height", h); var circles = svg.selectAll("circle") .data(dataset2) .enter() .append("circle") .attr("cx", function(d,i){ return i * 50 + d * 2; }).attr("cy", function(d,i){ return h/2; }).attr("r", function(d,i){ return d; }).attr("fill",function(d){ return "rgb(" + d*10 + ", 140, 255)" }) .attr("stroke", function(d){ return "rgb(0, 140, " + d*10 + ")"; }) .attr("stroke-width", function(d){ return d / 5; }); </script> .

" node--internal" : " node--leaf"); }) .attr("transform", (d) => { return `translate(${d.x},${d.y})`; }); nodeGroups .append("circle") .attr("r", 20) .attr("fill", (d, i) => color(i)); nodeGroups .append("text") .attr("dy", ".33em") .attr("font-size", "12px") .attr("text-anchor", "middle") .attr("fill", "#fff") .text((d) => d.data.name); </script> .

73.title: Code
73.content: Full code below. HTML Elements . These are HTML elements. <div class="overlay" id="overlay"></div> <div class="tree-container" id="tree-container"> <div class="toolbar"> <button onclick="enlarge()" id="enlarge-button" style="display: block;"> <i class="fa-solid fa-up-right-and-down-left-from-center"></i> </button> <button onclick="minimize()" id="minimize-button" style="display: none;"> <i class="fa-solid fa-minimize"></i> </button> </div> <h2>This is the Title</h2> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> <p>This is a centered popup window!</p> </div> . Style . Default styles . <style> .overlay { display: none; /* Hidden by default */ position: fixed; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.7); /* Semi-transparent background */ z-index: 1; /* Sit on top */ } .tree-container { display: block; width: 100%; /* Center the popup */ background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.451); padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px; box-shadow: 0 0 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); z-index: 2; /* Sit on top of the overlay */ } .tree-container .toolbar { display: flex; justify-content: flex-end; margin-bottom: 10px; } .tree-container .toolbar button { background: none; border: none; cursor: pointer; font-size: 1.2em; margin-left: 10px; } </style> . Javascript . Javascript code as below. <script> const overlay = document.getElementById("overlay"); const container = document.getElementById("tree-container"); const enlargeButton = document.getElementById("enlarge-button"); const minimizeButton = document.getElementById("minimize-button"); let originalPosition = { top: container.top, left: container.left, height: container.height, }; function enlarge() { overlay.style.display = "block"; container.style.position = "fixed"; container.style.top = "50%"; container.style.left = "50%"; container.style.height = `${window.innerHeight}px`; container.style.transform = "translate(-50%, -50%)"; enlargeButton.style.display = "none"; minimizeButton.style.display = "block"; } function minimize() { overlay.style.display = "none"; container.style.position = "static"; container.style.top = `${originalPosition.top}px`; container.style.height = `${originalPosition.height}px`; container.style.transform = "none"; enlargeButton.style.display = "block"; minimizeButton.style.display = "none"; } </script> .

117.title: å¸¸ç”¨Linux Commands
117.content: 54 Essential Linux Commands . | pwd: Show current working directory. | ls: list all files under the current working directly. | ls -l: show more details. | ls - lh: with more readable file size, like 3k, 20K, etc. | ls -a: show all files including hidden ones. | ls â€“color=auto: highlight folders using colors automatically. | . | clear: clear up current screen. Shortcut: Ctrl + l. | mkdir: create new directory. | cd: change current working directory. | cd {directory name} | cd {part of directory} and press tab: automatically match if there is. | cd -: back to previous directory. | cd / cd ~: change to home directory. | . | alias: make alias. For example, . | alias ls=â€ls â€“color=autoâ€ | alas cls=â€clearâ€ | . | which: show the path of executable path, for example, which pwd, which cd, etc. | whereis: show exectuable file, for example, whereis mkdir, whereis clear, etc. | man: get help on commands, for example, man clear, man ls, etc. | whatis: give quick summary about command. For example, whatis cd, whatis mkdir, etc. | touch: to create a new file. | echo: print messages or strings. For exmple, . | echo â€œhello worldâ€. | echo â€œhello worldâ€ > file.txt: the string will replace content in file.txt. | echo â€œhello worldâ€Â Â» file.txt: the string will be appended to file.txt. | . | cat: view content of file. | less: view content of file with pager. Continuous operation keys, . | j: scroll down | k: scroll up | f: move down a page | b: move up a page | /: search | q: quit | . | nano: edit a file. | vim: edit filr using vim editor. | cp: copy file. | mv: move or rename file. | rm: remove file. | rmdir: remove empty directory. | rm -r {dir}: to remove non-empty directory. | rm -i: remove after confirmation. | cmp: compare two files. | diff: show difference abour the two files. | whoami: show username. | adduser: add new user. | sudo: execute command using administrator, password is asked to provide. | su: switch user, password is to be provided. | exit: logout user. | userdel: remove user. For example, sudo userdel -r: delete user and everything of the user. | passwd: change password. | uname: show system name. | uname -a: show details of system. | apt . | sudo apt update: list all upgradable packages. | sudo apt upgrade: upgrade packages. | sudo apt install {package name} | . | wget: download file from internet, wget {url} | grep: search. For example, ls | grep xxx. | chmod: change file permission . | r: read | w: write | x: execution | . | ln | curl | jq | awk | sed | zip | unzip | find | ip | ping | free | df | ps | kill | pkill | top | htop | systemctl | history | Outro | .

132.title: Table of contents
132.content: . | Preparations | Setup Steps . | Step #1: Install above software, SDK and VScode extensions. | Step #2: Create MAUI Project in VSCode | Step #3: Run Application in Simulators | . | End | .

133.title: Preparations
133.content: The followings are used in my case. | Type | Resource | Remark | . | Hardware | Mackbook Pro (Apple silicon) | Development Machine | . | Software | Xcode 26.0.1 | By Nov-25, version 26.1 and above versions are not supported. | . | Software | Android Studio | Latest version | . | SDK | Android SDK | Latest version | . | SDK | Java SDK | Version >= 17 | . | Software | Visual Studio Code | Latest version | . | SDK | .NET SDK | version 9.0 | . | VSCode Extensions | C#, C# Dev Kit, .NET MAUI | Â  | .

134.title: Setup Steps
134.content: Â  . Step #1: Install above software, SDK and VScode extensions. Something important need pay attention to during installation. | Java SDK. Java runtime environment is one of key dependencies for others like Xcode, Android Studio, etc. So it is better to install it first. (Note: I downloaded from Microsoft (Download the Microsoft Build of OpenJDK) . Check if $JAVA_HOME and version is correctly configured or not. If correct path is retured, ignore the next JAVA_HOME configuration steps. # Check JAVA_HOME system variable % echo $JAVA_HOME # Check Java version % java -version . To configure $JAVA_HOME, find where java home is firstly using following commands (notes: not all of them are necessarily used.). Remember the path found out. % $(dirname $(readlink $(which javac)))/java_home # or use java command to find % java -XshowSettings:properties -version % java -XshowSettings:properties -version 2>&1 > /dev/null | grep 'java.home' java.home = /Users/{your username}}/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/corretto-19.0.2/Contents/Home . Configure $JAVA_HOME and \bin in $PATH in ~/.bashrc and ~/.zshrc files. Add the following lines in the end of the two files. # Add JAVA_HOME export JAVA_HOME="/Users/{your username}/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/corretto-19.0.2/Contents/Home" export PATH="$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH" . Open a new Terminal window to check if JAVA_HOME is correctly configured. # Check JAVA_HOME system variable % echo $JAVA_HOME # Check Java version % java -version . | Android Studio . Download from Google Developers - Android Studio . Open Android Studio, go to â€œSettingsâ€ â€“> â€œSDK Managerâ€ â€“> â€œSDK Toolsâ€ tab. Make sure â€œAndroid SDK Build-toolsâ€, â€œAndroid SDK Command-line Tools (latest)â€, â€œAndroid Emulatorâ€ and â€œAndroid SDK Platform-Toolsâ€ are selected and installed. Remember the Android SDK location. It is to be configured as $ANDROID_HOME sytem variable. Configure $ANDROID_HOME in ~/.bashrc and ~/.zshrc files. # Add ANDROID_HOME export ANDROID_HOME="/Users/{your username}/Library/Android/sdk" . Open a new Terminal window to check if ANDROID_HOME is correctly configured. % echo $ANDROID_HOME . | Xcode . Only Xcode command line might not be enough. Xcode app should be installed because device emulators are used for debugging and running locally. Donâ€™t install Xcode from Mac App Store directly because Microsoft MAUI may not support the latest Xcode version. In my case, Xcode 26.1 is not supported. I had to install Xcode 26.0 specially. Download Xcode from Apple Resources. Select â€œView available Xcode betasâ€ link (important). You may be asked for Apple account login. On the download page, slect the suitable version to download the installation package. The package is named like â€œXcode_26.0.1_Apple_silicon.xipâ€. Double click it to uncompress. This will take some time. Rename uncompressed file â€œXcodeâ€ as â€œXcode_26.0.1â€ to reflect version number. Copy the renamed Xcode file into â€œApplicationsâ€. It will trig the migration and take some time. Open the Xcode by run it through the command. You may be asked to download additional platform support like iOS simulator, watchOS, tvOS and visionOS. Choose as what simulator(s) you want to use. % /Applications/Xcode_26.0.1.app/Contents/MacOS/Xcode . Select menu â€œXcodeâ€ â€“> â€œSettingsâ€ â€“> â€œLocationsâ€, select â€œCommand Line Toolsâ€ to use the path â€œ/Applications/Xcode_26.0.1.appâ€ NOT the path of â€œDownloadâ€ folder or other versionâ€™s Xcode. | Visusal Studio Code . Download from official website. Install Visusal Studio Code and its Extensions including C#, C# Dev Kit and .NET MAUI. Install dotnet MAUI workload by the following command lines. % dotnet workload install maui # to check installed workload % dotnet workload list . | Accept Android Licenses . This step is to remove errors of .NET MAUI project in later steps. Make sure the previous steps are done. Android SDK is installed. Android Command Line Tool is installed. $JAVA_HOME and $ANDROID_HOME are configured correctly. Run command line using elevated permission (Assume the Android SDK is installed in the path below). Accept all the promopted questions by input â€œyâ€ (yes). % sudo /Users/{your username}/Library/Android/sdk/cmdline-tools/latest/bin/sdkmanager --licenses . | . Step #2: Create MAUI Project in VSCode . | Open VSCode. Open command palette by shortcut â€œCmd+Shift+Pâ€. | Select command â€œ.NET: New Projectâ€¦â€ â€“> â€œ.NET MAUI Appâ€ â€“> â€œ{your project name}â€â€¦ | Make sure the created new project is opened in VScode. By default, it can be runned without any changes. Our target is to run it in different platforms / simulators including Maccatalyst, iOS and Android. (Note: Windows platform is not supported in MacOS. Refer to the article) . | Your Operating System | Supported Target Platforms | . | Windows | Windows, Android | . | macOS | Android, iOS, macOS | . | Linux | Android | . | Open Terminal window by select menu â€œTerminalâ€. By default, the current path is the path of your .NET solution. For example, . # "dotnet-learn" is the path where my .net solution file is located. dotnet-learn % . | . Step #3: Run Application in Simulators . | In VSCode, open .csproj file in project folder. | VSCode will automatically do some pre-checks for a few seconds. You may find loading icons populated in status bar at the bottom of VSCode. | Once pre-checks are done. Click â€œ{} XMLâ€ toolbar button. It will show the readiness of running the project similar as below. | Select the links to configure the project. Normally you should configure as below. â€œLaunch Configurationâ€ > a simulator: Android/iOS phone, iPad, etc. â€œC# Startup Projectâ€ > your MAUI project name. â€œDebug Target Frameworkâ€ > .net9.0-iOS, .net9.0-android or .net9.0-maccatalyst . | After configuration, click â€œRun and Debugâ€ button in the left toolbar of VSCode. | Click the link â€œcreate a launch.json fileâ€. This will create launch.json file in project folder â€œ.vscode/launch.jsonâ€. Accept the default and some json configuraiton code lines are generated in the file. Save the default, for example â€œ.NET MAUIâ€ in my case. | In the â€œRun and Debugâ€ section, make sure â€œ.NET MAUIâ€ is selected in the dropdown. Click the arrow button or press F5 to run the application. | After the build is done, the select simulator will be started. Your app will be installed and started in the simulator. | You may play the app to experience the demo. | You can also switch to different simulator and platform by change the configuration. | .

135.title: End
135.content: Till now, the first MAUI project is set up and able to run successfully in different simulators of platforms. Enjoy MAUI for cross-platforms development and have fun! .

136.title: MAUI Development (MacOS)
136.content: This article mainly focus on setting up a local MAUI development environment in MacOS. It includes the toolings, detailed steps and also a small hello-world demo. Finally the demo is able to run in Android, iOS and MacOS emulators successfully. So, letâ€™s startâ€¦ .

140.title: Table of contents
140.content: . | Assumptions | Targets | Step1 - Pagefind Setup in Local Environment | Step 2: Integrate Pagefind into GitHub Actions | .

141.title: Assumptions
141.content: . | IDE environment: Windows + Visual Studio Code | A static blog website built using Jekyll framework. | The website is hosted in GitHub Pages and the source is from main branch of GitHub repository with default Jekyll configuration. | Local development/debugging environment is set up. | . For Jekyll website set-up, you may refer to my another articles how to set up Jekyll for personal webiste.

142.title: Targets
142.content: . | To set up Pagefind in existing local development/debugging environment. | Enable content indexing and search for the published _site directory. | Configure GitHub workflow action to automatically enable Pagefind for production website in GitHub Pages. | .

143.title: Step1 - Pagefind Setup in Local Environment
143.content: . | Set up nodejs | Open website source code using VSCode. | Create folder â€œ_pluginsâ€ under the root folder. | Create a file named â€œpagefind_hook.rbâ€ and update it using the code lines below. Jekyll::Hooks.register :site, :post_write do |site| puts ">>> Pagefind hook triggered for #{site.dest}" system("npx pagefind --source \"#{site.dest}\"") end . | Create â€œsearch.mdâ€ file for Pagefind search page. Code as below. --- layout: default title: Site Search permalink: /search/ --- <link href="/_pagefind/pagefind-ui.css" rel="stylesheet" /> <script src="/_pagefind/pagefind-ui.js"></script> <div id="search"></div> <script> window.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", (event) => { new PagefindUI({ element: "#search", showSubResults: true }); }); </script> . | Run command to indexing content under _site folder. jekyll serve ... >>> Pagefind hook triggered for C:/Users/xxx/source/repos/xxx/_site Running Pagefind v1.4.0 (Extended) Running from: "C:/Users/xxx/source/repos/xxx" Source: "_site" Output: "_site\\pagefind ... | Preview search by â€œhttps://localhost:4000/searchâ€ | .

144.title: Step 2: Integrate Pagefind into GitHub Actions
144.content: By default, . | GitHub Pages builds websites using Jekyll in â€œsafe modeâ€. | In safe mode, custom plugins in â€œ_plugins/â€ are ignored. That means the pagefind_hook.rb never runs on GitHubâ€™s servers. | Pagefind itself is a Node-based tool, not a Ruby gem, so GitHub Pages wonâ€™t install or execute it during the build. | . To enable Pagefind, we have to override using customized GitHub action. Hereâ€™re steps: . | Goto GitHub and open your repository. | Navigate to â€œSettings > Pagesâ€. | Under â€œBuild and deploymentâ€ section. Change Source from â€œDeploy from a branchâ€ to â€œGitHub Actionsâ€. | Click â€œConfigureâ€ button of Jekyll template. It will automatically create a yaml file â€œjekyll.ymlâ€. | Rename to â€œ.github/workflows/jekyll_node_pagefind_deploy.ymlâ€. | Update the yml file. Find the code below... env: JEKYLL_ENV: production . Add below code lines after above lines. # ğŸ‘‰ Add Node + Pagefind here - name: Setup Node.js uses: actions/setup-node@v4 with: node-version: '20' - name: Install Pagefind run: npm install -g pagefind - name: Run Pagefind run: pagefind --source "_site" - name: Upload artifact # Automatically uploads an artifact from the './_site' directory by default uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3 . | Commit the GitHub action. It will automaticall trigger the build and deployment. | Review final result by â€œhttps://yoursite/searchâ€. | .

151.content: Artificial Intelligence (äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½) . Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making. äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ï¼ˆAIï¼‰æ˜¯è®¡ç®—æœºç³»ç»Ÿæ‰§è¡Œé€šå¸¸ä¸äººç±»æ™ºèƒ½ç›¸å…³çš„ä»»åŠ¡çš„èƒ½åŠ›ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚å­¦ä¹ ã€æ¨ç†ã€è§£å†³é—®é¢˜ã€æ„ŸçŸ¥å’Œå†³ç­–ã€‚ .

152.title: E
152.content: Expert Systems (ä¸“å®¶ç³»ç»Ÿ) . Expert Systems are designed to simulate the decision-making ability of human experts. These systems use a set of predefined â€œif-thenâ€ rules and knowledge from specialists in specific fields to make informed decisions similar to how a medical professional would diagnose a disease. They are useful in areas where expert knowledge is important but not always easily accessible. ä¸“å®¶ç³»ç»Ÿæ—¨åœ¨æ¨¡æ‹Ÿäººç±»ä¸“å®¶çš„å†³ç­–èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚è¿™äº›ç³»ç»Ÿä½¿ç”¨ä¸€å¥—é¢„å®šä¹‰çš„â€œå¦‚æœ-é‚£ä¹ˆâ€è§„åˆ™å’Œç‰¹å®šé¢†åŸŸä¸“å®¶çš„çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œåšå‡ºç±»ä¼¼äºåŒ»ç–—ä¸“ä¸šäººå‘˜è¯Šæ–­ç–¾ç—…çš„æ˜æ™ºå†³ç­–ã€‚å®ƒä»¬åœ¨ä¸“å®¶çŸ¥è¯†é‡è¦ä½†ä¸æ˜“è·å–çš„é¢†åŸŸéå¸¸æœ‰ç”¨ã€‚ .

153.title: G
153.content: Generative Artificial Intelligence (ç”Ÿæˆå¼äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½) . Generative AI (GenAI) refers to artificial intelligence systems, often trained on massive datasets, that create new, original content like text, images, code, or music, rather than just classifying data or making decisions like traditional AI. These models learn patterns from existing data to generate novel outputs, powering tools from ChatGPT (text) to DALL-E (images), automating tasks, enhancing creativity, and transforming industries by understanding and producing human-like material in response to prompts. ç”Ÿæˆå¼äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ï¼ˆGenAIï¼‰æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œé€šå¸¸åœ¨æµ·é‡æ•°æ®é›†ä¸Šè¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒï¼Œèƒ½å¤Ÿåˆ›ä½œæ–°çš„ã€åŸåˆ›çš„å†…å®¹ï¼Œå¦‚æ–‡æœ¬ã€å›¾åƒã€ä»£ç æˆ–éŸ³ä¹ï¼Œè€Œä¸ä»…ä»…åƒä¼ ç»Ÿäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½é‚£æ ·è¿›è¡Œæ•°æ®åˆ†ç±»æˆ–å†³ç­–ã€‚è¿™äº›æ¨¡å‹ä»ç°æœ‰æ•°æ®ä¸­å­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å¼ä»¥ç”Ÿæˆæ–°çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼Œé©±åŠ¨ä» ChatGPTï¼ˆæ–‡æœ¬ï¼‰åˆ° DALL-Eï¼ˆå›¾åƒï¼‰çš„å·¥å…·ï¼Œè‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ä»»åŠ¡ã€å¢å¼ºåˆ›æ„ï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡ç†è§£å’Œç”Ÿæˆç±»ä¼¼äººç±»çš„å†…å®¹æ¥å“åº”æç¤ºï¼Œä»è€Œæ”¹å˜å„è¡Œå„ä¸šã€‚ .

154.title: M
154.content: Machine Learning (ML, æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ ) . Machine Learning is a subset of artificial intelligence (AI) that focuses on building systems that can learn from and make decisions based on data. Instead of being explicitly programmed to perform a task, a machine learning model uses algorithms to identify patterns within data and improve its performance over time without human intervention. æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ æ˜¯äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ï¼ˆAIï¼‰çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå­é›†ï¼Œä¸“æ³¨äºæ„å»ºèƒ½å¤Ÿä»æ•°æ®ä¸­å­¦ä¹ å¹¶åŸºäºæ•°æ®åšå‡ºå†³ç­–çš„ç³»ç»Ÿã€‚æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å‹ä¸æ˜¯é€šè¿‡æ˜ç¡®ç¼–ç¨‹æ¥æ‰§è¡Œä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨ç®—æ³•è¯†åˆ«æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œå¹¶éšç€æ—¶é—´çš„æ¨ç§»åœ¨æ— éœ€äººå·¥å¹²é¢„çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹æé«˜å…¶æ€§èƒ½ã€‚ . Models (æ¨¡å‹) . AI models are programs that learn from data and make decisions or predictions based on what theyâ€™ve learned. These models help AI perform tasks by recognizing patterns in data similar to how humans learn from experience. Different models use various learning approaches depending on how they are trained. äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½æ¨¡å‹æ˜¯é€šè¿‡æ•°æ®å­¦ä¹ å¹¶æ ¹æ®æ‰€å­¦å†…å®¹åšå‡ºå†³ç­–æˆ–é¢„æµ‹çš„ç¨‹åºã€‚è¿™äº›æ¨¡å‹é€šè¿‡è¯†åˆ«æ•°æ®ä¸­çš„æ¨¡å¼æ¥å¸®åŠ©äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½å®Œæˆä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œç±»ä¼¼äºäººç±»é€šè¿‡ç»éªŒå­¦ä¹ çš„æ–¹å¼ã€‚ä¸åŒçš„æ¨¡å‹æ ¹æ®è®­ç»ƒæ–¹å¼ä½¿ç”¨ä¸åŒçš„å­¦ä¹ æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ . 155.title: N
155.content: Natural Language Processing (NLP, è‡ªç„¶è¯­è¨€å¤„ç†) . Natural Language Processing (NLP) allows machines to understand and interact with human language in a way that feels natural. It enables speech recognition systems like Siri or Alexa to interpret what we say and respond accordingly. It combines linguistics and computer science to help computers process, understand and generate human language allowing for tasks like language translation, sentiment analysis and real-time conversation. è‡ªç„¶è¯­è¨€å¤„ç†ï¼ˆNLPï¼‰ä½¿æœºå™¨èƒ½å¤Ÿä»¥è‡ªç„¶çš„æ–¹å¼ç†è§£å’Œä¸äººç±»è¯­è¨€äº’åŠ¨ã€‚å®ƒä½¿è¯­éŸ³è¯†åˆ«ç³»ç»Ÿï¼ˆå¦‚ Siri æˆ– Alexaï¼‰èƒ½å¤Ÿç†è§£æˆ‘ä»¬çš„è¯­è¨€å¹¶ä½œå‡ºç›¸åº”çš„å›åº”ã€‚è‡ªç„¶è¯­è¨€å¤„ç†ç»“åˆäº†è¯­è¨€å­¦å’Œè®¡ç®—æœºç§‘å­¦ï¼Œå¸®åŠ©è®¡ç®—æœºå¤„ç†ã€ç†è§£å’Œç”Ÿæˆè‡ªç„¶è¯­è¨€ï¼Œä»è€Œå®ç°è¯­è¨€ç¿»è¯‘ã€æƒ…æ„Ÿåˆ†æå’Œå®æ—¶å¯¹è¯ç­‰ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚ . 162.title: AI Introduction
162.content: AI, or artificial intelligence, is the ability of a computer system to learn from past data and errors, enabling it to make increasingly accurate predictions for future behavior. This encompasses a broad range of activities, such as problem solving, speech recognition, learning, and decision making. äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ï¼ˆAIï¼‰æ˜¯è®¡ç®—æœºç³»ç»Ÿä»è¿‡å»çš„æ•°æ®å’Œé”™è¯¯ä¸­å­¦ä¹ çš„èƒ½åŠ›ï¼Œä½¿å…¶èƒ½å¤Ÿå¯¹æœªæ¥è¡Œä¸ºåšå‡ºè¶Šæ¥è¶Šå‡†ç¡®çš„é¢„æµ‹ã€‚è¿™æ¶µç›–äº†å¹¿æ³›çš„æ´»åŠ¨ï¼Œå¦‚é—®é¢˜è§£å†³ã€è¯­éŸ³è¯†åˆ«ã€å­¦ä¹ å’Œå†³ç­–ã€‚ . Data, models, algorithms, and neural networks are building blocks of AI. AI uses data for learning and reasoning, models and algorithms for knowledge representation and processing, and neural networks for learning from large datasets and accomplishing complex tasks. æ•°æ®ã€æ¨¡å‹ã€ç®—æ³•å’Œç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œæ˜¯äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½çš„æ„å»ºæ¨¡å—ã€‚äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½ä½¿ç”¨æ•°æ®è¿›è¡Œå­¦ä¹ å’Œæ¨ç†ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨æ¨¡å‹å’Œç®—æ³•è¿›è¡ŒçŸ¥è¯†è¡¨ç¤ºå’Œå¤„ç†ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œä»å¤§å‹æ•°æ®é›†ä¸­å­¦ä¹ å¹¶å®Œæˆå¤æ‚ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚ . AI has numerous real-world applications. For example, in healthcare, it can be used for diagnosing diseases, detecting tumors, and developing patient treatment plans. äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½åœ¨ç°å®ä¸–ç•Œä¸­æœ‰è®¸å¤šåº”ç”¨ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œåœ¨åŒ»ç–—é¢†åŸŸï¼Œå®ƒå¯ç”¨äºè¯Šæ–­ç–¾ç—…ã€æ£€æµ‹è‚¿ç˜¤ä»¥åŠåˆ¶å®šæ‚£è€…æ²»ç–—æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚ . https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/artificial-intelligence/what-is-artificial-intelligence-ai/ .

173.title: 2026/01/05 Sentences
173.content: Is truly open-source AI possible? There are two sides to the software industry. One faces outwards, with products and services generating billions for trillion-dollar companies. The other faces inwards, creating, updating and sharingâ€”often for freeâ€”the basic software tools that make the digital world tick. è½¯ä»¶è¡Œä¸šæœ‰ä¸¤é¢æ€§ã€‚ä¸€é¢æœå¤–ï¼Œäº§å“å’ŒæœåŠ¡ä¸ºä¸‡äº¿ç¾å…ƒçš„å…¬å¸åˆ›é€ æ•°åäº¿ç¾å…ƒçš„æ”¶å…¥ã€‚å¦ä¸€é¢æœå†…ï¼Œåˆ›é€ ã€æ›´æ–°å’Œåˆ†äº«ï¼ˆé€šå¸¸æ˜¯å…è´¹çš„ï¼‰æ„æˆæ•°å­—ä¸–ç•ŒåŸºç¡€çš„è½¯ä»¶å·¥å…·ã€‚ . This second side is known as open-source software. It underpins (å·©å›º) platforms like Googleâ€™s Android, Appleâ€™s iOS, and major web browsers. By making software freely available, developers can strengthen their code through collaboration (åˆä½œ), gain trust by proving its reliability and earn recognition from peers. Some open-source projects even make money by selling support to users of the free products. è¿™ç¬¬äºŒé¢è¢«ç§°ä¸ºå¼€æºè½¯ä»¶ã€‚å®ƒæ”¯æ’‘ç€ï¼ˆå·©å›ºï¼‰è°·æ­Œçš„ Androidã€è‹¹æœçš„ iOS å’Œä¸»è¦çš„ç½‘ç»œæµè§ˆå™¨ç­‰å¹³å°ã€‚é€šè¿‡å…è´¹æä¾›è½¯ä»¶ï¼Œå¼€å‘è€…å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡åä½œï¼ˆåˆä½œï¼‰æ¥å¼ºåŒ–ä»–ä»¬çš„ä»£ç ï¼Œé€šè¿‡è¯æ˜å…¶å¯é æ€§æ¥èµ¢å¾—ä¿¡ä»»ï¼Œå¹¶è·å¾—åŒè¡Œçš„è®¤å¯ã€‚ä¸€äº›å¼€æºé¡¹ç›®ç”šè‡³é€šè¿‡å‘å…è´¹äº§å“çš„ç”¨æˆ·é”€å”®æ”¯æŒæ¥èµšé’±ã€‚ . Unluckily, modern tech giants have stretched the term into meaninglessness. Many so-called â€œfreeâ€ products are restricted, developed in secrecy and unable to bring about true innovation. This has led to a heated debate about the real meaning of open source in the age of AI. ä¸å¹¸çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œç°ä»£ç§‘æŠ€å·¨å¤´å·²ç»å°†è¿™ä¸ªè¯å»¶ä¼¸åˆ°æ¯«æ— æ„ä¹‰çš„åœ°æ­¥ã€‚è®¸å¤šæ‰€è°“çš„â€œå…è´¹â€äº§å“å—åˆ°é™åˆ¶ï¼Œåœ¨ç§˜å¯†çŠ¶æ€ä¸‹å¼€å‘ï¼Œæ— æ³•å¸¦æ¥çœŸæ­£çš„åˆ›æ–°ã€‚è¿™å¼•å‘äº†ä¸€åœºå…³äºäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½æ—¶ä»£å¼€æºçœŸæ­£å«ä¹‰çš„æ¿€çƒˆè¾©è®ºã€‚ . In traditional software, the term is well-defined. A developer lets others use their original lines of code written to create a piece of software. This allows any other developer to download, modify (ä¿®æ”¹) and repurpose the code. Typically, the original developer will ask for the modified version to be shared, too. Over time, original code can evolve into entirely new products. Android, for instance, is based on Linux, originally written for computers. åœ¨ä¼ ç»Ÿè½¯ä»¶ä¸­ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªæœ¯è¯­æœ‰æ˜ç¡®çš„å®šä¹‰ã€‚å¼€å‘è€…å…è®¸å…¶ä»–äººä½¿ç”¨ä»–ä»¬ä¸ºåˆ›å»ºè½¯ä»¶è€Œç¼–å†™çš„åŸå§‹ä»£ç è¡Œã€‚è¿™ä½¿å¾—ä»»ä½•å…¶ä»–å¼€å‘è€…éƒ½å¯ä»¥ä¸‹è½½ã€ä¿®æ”¹ï¼ˆä¿®æ”¹ï¼‰å’Œé‡æ–°åˆ©ç”¨ä»£ç ã€‚é€šå¸¸ï¼ŒåŸå§‹å¼€å‘è€…ä¼šè¦æ±‚ä¹Ÿåˆ†äº«ä¿®æ”¹åçš„ç‰ˆæœ¬ã€‚éšç€æ—¶é—´çš„æ¨ç§»ï¼ŒåŸå§‹ä»£ç å¯ä»¥æ¼”å˜æˆå…¨æ–°çš„äº§å“ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼ŒAndroid å°±æ˜¯åŸºäºæœ€åˆä¸ºè®¡ç®—æœºç¼–å†™çš„ Linuxã€‚ . Meta, the parent company of Facebook, proudly claims that its large language model (LLM), Llama 3, is â€œopen sourceâ€. However, the tech giant also places restrictions on its use, including a ban on using the model to build products with more than 700 million monthly active users. Other labs have also released LLMs for free use, but with similar limits. Facebook çš„æ¯å…¬å¸ Meta è‡ªè±ªåœ°å®£ç§°å…¶å¤§å‹è¯­è¨€æ¨¡å‹ï¼ˆLLMï¼‰Llama 3 æ˜¯â€œå¼€æºâ€çš„ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œè¿™å®¶ç§‘æŠ€å·¨å¤´ä¹Ÿå¯¹å…¶ä½¿ç”¨æ–½åŠ äº†é™åˆ¶ï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬ç¦æ­¢ä½¿ç”¨è¯¥æ¨¡å‹æ„å»ºæ¯æœˆæ´»è·ƒç”¨æˆ·è¶…è¿‡ 7 äº¿çš„äº§å“ã€‚å…¶ä»–å®éªŒå®¤ä¹Ÿå‘å¸ƒäº†ä¾›å…è´¹ä½¿ç”¨çš„ LLMï¼Œä½†ä¹Ÿæœ‰ç±»ä¼¼çš„é™åˆ¶ã€‚ . What Meta shares freely is the weights (æƒé‡) of the artificial neurons (äººå·¥ç¥ç»å…ƒ) in its LLM, rather than all the source code and training data. This is certainly not sufficient for someone to build their own version of Llama 3 from scratch. Unlike traditional software development, AI training involves creating a blueprint of the model and feeding it large amounts of data, which the system then uses to adjust its structure through a series of unpredictable steps. Over time, the model improves its performance to an acceptable level. Even if someone were to train an AI model using the same data and hardware as Llama 3, the result would not be identical. That limits the benefits of the open-source approach. While the code can be examined, thereâ€™s no certainty that it will perform exactly as the original. There are other challenges when it comes to truly open-source AI. Training a cutting-edge AI model that can compete with the latest releases from OpenAI or its peers, for example, costs at least $1 billion. This discourages the developers who have already spent a fortune from sharing. There are also safety concerns. The powerful models may be misused for dangerous purposes, such as spreading harmful content. åœ¨å®ç°çœŸæ­£çš„å¼€æºäººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½æ–¹é¢è¿˜å­˜åœ¨å…¶ä»–æŒ‘æˆ˜ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼Œè®­ç»ƒä¸€ä¸ªå¯ä»¥ä¸ OpenAI æˆ–å…¶åŒè¡Œæœ€æ–°å‘å¸ƒçš„äº§å“ç«äº‰çš„å°–ç«¯äººå·¥æ™ºèƒ½æ¨¡å‹çš„æˆæœ¬è‡³å°‘ä¸º 10 äº¿ç¾å…ƒã€‚è¿™é˜»ç¢äº†å·²ç»èŠ±è´¹å·¨èµ„çš„å¼€å‘è€…è¿›è¡Œåˆ†äº«ã€‚è¿˜å­˜åœ¨å®‰å…¨éšæ‚£ã€‚å¼ºå¤§çš„æ¨¡å‹å¯èƒ½è¢«æ»¥ç”¨ç”¨äºå±é™©ç›®çš„ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ä¼ æ’­æœ‰å®³å†…å®¹ã€‚ .
